body: This was actually needed. If you don't do that, Markdown removes everything between {{ and }} :(
dead code ?
Yea, but there's a comment below with instructions for getting more debugging info which requires that `proc` exists. So I just did this. Happy to end up with this gone eventually though.
I was kind of disappointed that we had to go from one concat to three. Could this be precomputed at the top of the module?
Could also have `mountComponent` build up an array of string fragments and then do one big `.join("")` at the end.
If I checked it correctly, this was only chapter mentioning the key attribute.
It's actually in `04-multiple-components.md`. There was a copy made and this old version got left behind and checked in. Thanks for looking out though!
Thanks!  I build really awesome stuff with this component, proud to use v.0.4 ;)
It seems unlikely that this would conflict with anything, but perhaps it makes sense to call this `data-react-danger-index`?
This invariant broke react-page which calls this with `document` (`nodeType === 9`)

So I currently develop using React and commonJS/npm. This causes it to fail. How about making this a commonJS module with a single export? Packagers could just as easily replace that "version module" instead of looking for `__VERSION__`.

I just ran into the same thing when trying to test react-page. Are you suggesting making a new ReactVersion.js with

```
module.exports = __VERSION__;
```

and then simply including that here?
Thank you!
Can't this just be `props[propName] !== undefined`?
Do you mean `props[propName] === undefined`? After JavaScript 1.8.5 (when `undefined` becomes non-writeable), yeah.
Er, yes. I feel like uglifyjs might change `undefined` to `void 0` but I don't remember completely.
Typo? Looks like there's an extra `}`
JSX isn't XML-like?
I like this change
JS community is allergic to XML
Can't we just use our existing console polyfill?
Where is it?
This doesn't appear to error if this.instance().context has keys that contextNameToExpectedValue does not -- intended? The name sounds like they should match up in both directions.

i copy/pasted this from scalarPropsEqual... good question

"only works with scalars" is also not true at all... expect.toEqual supports more than scalars.
You did not update the examples of the main page and they fatal because of your diff :( Can't wait for you to fix it so we can ship it!
Shouldn't clearInterval be defined somewhere in this example?
No -- like setTimeout, it's a browser builtin: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window.clearInterval.
